proxyLocation: lying flat across the top-center of the desk
utilizationMethod: Grip the keyboard firmly by one of its short side edges so that the rest of the board projects outward like a hammer head. When you swing your arm, the bulk of the keys and internal weight create noticeable inertia, giving a sense of a heavy striking tool. The key-bed’s hard plastic surface can be bumped lightly against your palm or another surface to feel a rigid impact, while the large mass that extends beyond your hand mimics the top-heavy feel of a real hammer.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The hammer should convey significant weight concentrated in the metal head, creating a distinctly top-heavy feel. Users would expect substantial resistance when lifting and notable momentum during swinging motions.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Because the hammer is a grasp object with a cylindrical handle roughly 38 cm long, users will wrap their fingers and thumb around the handle in a power-grip, most often near the lower end to maximize leverage (dominant hand). Some users may steady the head with the non-dominant hand when positioning it. Typical manipulation patterns include raising the tool by flexing the elbow and shoulder, then accelerating it in an arcing swing; the wrist stays semi-locked until the end of the stroke, when it may snap forward for extra speed. The top-heavy inertia means the user immediately feels the metal head trying to lag behind when lifting and trying to carry through when stopping; this encourages deliberate follow-through motions and requires counter-torque in the forearm to halt recoil. During impact the virtual head should appear to stop abruptly while a vibration or ‘kick’ propagates up the handle, conveying a rigid, high-hardness collision. If the user changes grip (e.g., choking up close to the head) the perceived moment of inertia drops, enabling more precise light taps. Users may also rotate the wrist to flip the striking face or to orient the hammer for side blows. In essence: firm cylindrical power-grip, arm-swinging strike motions, pronounced momentum and jolt feedback on impact, with the object visually and aurally reacting like a solid steel-headed tool.

proxyLocation: top left of the desk near the keyboard
utilizationMethod: Hold the cup by pinching the bottom rim between thumb and fingers, letting the fuller, wider body act as the metal head that extends beyond your grip. The offset mass—especially if the cup already contains liquid—provides a slight top-heaviness. Swinging your arm lets you feel the cup’s momentum and any sloshing weight, loosely approximating the follow-through sensation of a hammer strike.

proxyLocation: lying horizontally at the upper right of the desk
utilizationMethod: Clasp the pen near its metal cap so that most of the barrel extends outward beyond your fist. Though light, the pen’s rigid, cylindrical body naturally invites a power-grip similar to a small hammer handle. Rapid wrist flicks let you feel the pen’s slight inertia and give the sensation of precise tap-hammering, useful for simulating lighter, more controlled strikes in VR.

proxyLocation: bottom left of the desk, opened flat
utilizationMethod: Grab the notebook by the spiral binding with your fist wrapped fully around the wire spine. The stack of pages forms a broad, weighty ‘head’ that sticks out from your grip. Swinging it produces a clear moment of inertia because the paper mass lags and then follows through, echoing the feel of a hammer’s metal head. Lightly tapping the page block against your other palm gives a firm, sudden stop that reinforces the impact sensation.

physicalObject: black mechanical computer keyboard with function keys
proxyLocation: top-center of the desk, directly in front of the monitor position
utilizationMethod: Use one of the larger keys (e.g., the space-bar or Enter key) as the press surface. Rest your index finger on that key and push straight down until the key bottoms out. The key’s built-in switch and return spring give a clear travel distance, progressive resistance, an audible click, and automatic rebound—closely mimicking the feel of depressing and releasing the virtual red button.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Pressing the button to trigger critical actions
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The red cap responds to downward pressure by traveling vertically into the base assembly. The travel distance is about 4cm. Users should feel progressive compression resistance.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: As a contact object, users will typically extend an index finger or thumb and apply a straight-on press to the center of the red cap. Alternative interactions include a palm slap or fist bump when urgency is implied, but all involve a perpendicular downward motion. The press is momentary: finger descends ~4 cm, compressing an internal spring that produces increasing resistance; tactile feedback peaks at full travel, often accompanied by a click. Users then release, letting the spring return the cap so the finger loses contact after rebound. The contact area is fingertip-sized (15 cm diameter cap gives ample target). Interaction duration is brief (≤0.5 s) unless the scene requires a sustained hold, in which case the user must maintain steady pressure against the spring. Visually the button depresses, audibly clicks, and resets; haptically the user perceives progressive force, a soft bottom-out, followed by a lighter upward force as the cap returns.

utilizationMethod: Turn the cup upside-down so its open end rests on the desk. Place your fingertip on the center of the cup’s base and press down. The thin plastic base flexes slightly and your finger pad compresses approximately 4 cm against the desk, creating a soft but noticeable spring-like resistance and rebound from your own tissue—allowing a button-press gesture with a diameter similar to the virtual cap.

proxyLocation: top-right of the desk, lying horizontally
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen vertically, tip downward, and press the felt nib straight onto the desk surface. The felt tip compresses a few millimeters and then springs back when released, giving a miniaturized version of a button press that supplies gentle resistance and a clear stop point.

physicalObject: spiral-bound graph paper notebook with handwritten notes
proxyLocation: bottom-left of the desk, opened flat
utilizationMethod: Keep the notebook closed so the full page stack forms a soft block. Place your fingertip on the center of the front cover and press downward. The pages compress slightly (an elastic travel of a few millimeters), then push back when you release, imitating a shallow button press with mild progressive resistance.
